body:
### Problem

Full MWE:
```python
import subprocess
import os

editor = os.environ['EDITOR']
command = [editor, "foo.txt"]
proc = subprocess.Popen(command, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, encoding='utf-8')
_stdout, stderr = proc.communicate()
print(stderr)
```

Regression:
```
$ EDITOR=nvim python sample.py

^[]11;rgb:fbfb/f1f1/c7c7^[\⏎                            
$ 11;rgb:fbfb/f1f1/c7c7
```

Expected:
```
$ EDITOR=vim python sample.py
<no output>
```

Smaller test bench showing stderr output when using `nvim --clean`:
```
nvim --clean +qa 2> stderr.log && cat stderr.log
+q5463;524742;73657472676266;73657472676262$qm^[]11;rgb:ffff/ffff/ffff^G⏎                                                                                                
$ 11;rgb:ffff/ffff/ffff    
```

There is garbage output in stderr where there wasn't before.

Scripts that work with $EDITOR and capture stderr will have problems interpreting this since it seems to contain some escape codes.

### Steps to reproduce

nvim --clean +qa 2> stderr.log && cat stderr.log

### Expected behavior

There should be no output. I verified on 0.9.5:
```
~ ❯ bob use 0.9.5 && nvim --clean +qa 2> stderr.log && cat stderr.log
Mar 06 11:08:56.136  INFO You can now use v0.9.5!

```

### Nvim version (nvim -v)

NVIM v0.11.0-dev-1912+g0c0352783f

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

no, vim 9.1

### Operating system/version

macOS

### Terminal name/version

Terminal.app, Wezterm 20240203-110809-5046fc22, Ghostty 1.1.2

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-256color

### Installation

bob

comment_data.body: Terminal.app is garbage; please use a standard conforming terminal (ghostty, kitty, iTerm2).

> Terminal.app is garbage; please use a standard conforming terminal (ghostty, kitty, iTerm2).

Don't think that's relevant here. Repros on Ghostty, WezTerm for me. I mentioned Terminal.app since it comes natively with the OS, so I figured it would be easier to repro.

That is relevant information that would be good to add to the description. These issues are usually due to problems with DEC sequences not being interpreted properly (which Terminal.app is particularly bad at).
Gotcha, point taken. I'll also add this is on `fish, version 4.0.0` if that makes a difference, although I can repro on `zsh 5.9 (arm-apple-darwin22.6.0)`.
It would also be good to state your _actual_ problem here; the repro steps are very academic (normally you'd use `nvim --headless` if you don't actually want to start an editor instance).

To clarify, the stderr appears when `nvim` is exited, *regardless of headless.* The headless is there to provide a clean repro bench.

Right now, I edit stuff, quit the editor, and see stderr output. This interferes with scripts that launch `$EDITOR` and capture stderr from the editor for output. This is a regression from earlier `nvim` builds, as well as `vim` which are clean when it comes to stderr otherwise.

Ok, that (latter) I cannot reproduce. So we need a reproducer for the _actual_ issue.

(Also, your repro does _not_ have `--headless`, hence the control sequences in _your_ output.)

To be clear, there were a lot of _intended_ changes regarding this since 0.9.5, which significantly improve the standards compliance. So the change is expected and desired, per se; any regression would have to be much more specific.

> (Also, your repro does not have --headless, hence the control sequences in your output.)

Sorry, I meant `--clean` here. Should have looked at my original repro steps. I can share a MWE python script that demonstrates this interference as well if that would help

```python
import subprocess
import os

editor = os.environ['EDITOR']
command = [editor, "foo.txt"]
proc = subprocess.Popen(command, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, encoding='utf-8')
_stdout, stderr = proc.communicate()
print(stderr)
```

Regression:
```
$ EDITOR=nvim python sample.py

^[]11;rgb:fbfb/f1f1/c7c7^[\⏎                            
$ 11;rgb:fbfb/f1f1/c7c7
```

Expected:
```
$ EDITOR=vim python sample.py
<no output>
```
Again, why can't you use `nvim --headless` for this?

Sorry, I'm not understanding how `nvim --headless` would work here. Would it look like this?
```
$ EDITOR="nvim --headless" python sample.py
```
For this use case, I want to open up the editor UI so the user can manipulate some text before sending it back to the program.

This is why I am asking you to give a full, realistic, reproducer. We need to nail down where exactly the assumptions behind the current implementation are breaking down (and many similar use cases, e.g., for git commit messages, are working just fine!)

> This is why I am asking you to give a full, realistic, reproducer.

The snippet above is representative of a use-case in a script I maintain. I can't share the actual script since it's closed source. I'm also not claiming this is the typical logging use case, just the one that I happen to use. And I observe a regression in what appears in stderr compared to earlier Neovim, Vim, and other editors. Neovim is the only one that stands out from the ones I've tried.

If the answer is "don't print stderr when calling an editor in subprocess", I can make that change, especially if similar use cases are working fine.

I encounter this issue myself as a human when opening/closing too fast (e.g. i realize i opened the wrong file). 

I can reproduce on `foot` terminal on arch linux with:
```
$ nvim --clean -c 'q!'
$ 8;59;105;1062;945t
```

But the same issue doesn't happen with ghostty on macos X for me.
Yes, it's (now) very important to get the `TERMINAL` correct, which I suspect is an issue for "embedded" use as in the (edited) OP.
"Since 0.9.5" is useful info. Can someone bisect to an exact commit?
bisected to e41368f3bc1d08d900425608bd199f585d6fce59 (@gpanders).

>  nvim --clean +qa 2> stderr.log && cat stderr.log
> +q5463;524742;73657472676266;73657472676262$qm^[]11;rgb:ffff/ffff/ffff^G⏎                                                                                                
> $ 11;rgb:ffff/ffff/ffff    

I don't think this is directly the actual contents of `stderr.log`. Likely stderr.log contains completely valid ANSI sequences to query info from the terminal, and what you see is the response. Normally this response is sent while neovim is _running_  with the terminal in raw mode, and able to process it. However, when you `cat` it afterwards in a cooked terminal you insted get garbage at the shell prompt.

This might be a documentation issue. When neovim is used with an interactive TUI, stderr is expected to refer to the controlling terminal. better to use a separate side-channel if you need a logging interface.

The original repro here just seems like a user error (why are you starting interactive `nvim` UI and printing its stderr?). 

But this case looks suspicious:
 
> ```
> $ nvim --clean -c 'q!'
> $ 8;59;105;1062;945t
> ```

Either we are emitting partial termcodes on exit (race condition?) or the terminal doesn't understand the termcodes (user error, wrong $TERM/terminfo).
That depends on the terminal (and the `$TERMINAL`). (Works fine for me on Ghostty, for example.)

I bisected using `nvim --clean -c 'q!'` and ghostty. Though it doesn't always reproduce so I wrapped it in a while loop: `while VIMRUNTIME=$(git rev-parse --show-toplevel)/runtime build/bin/nvim --clean -c 'q!'; do echo; done`.
@rmuir would you mind opening a new issue? The original issue here is nonsense.

> I bisected using `nvim --clean -c 'q!'` and ghostty.

Hmm, seems to be indeed timing dependent. It _sometimes_ happens for me when I spam the command:
```
^[[48;100;110;2700;1540t⏎
```
Looks indeed like a resize event. @gpanders ?

The TUI does not wait for any pending potential responses when it is asked to exit early. It could do so, but then there would be an extra X ms delay for `nvim --clean -c 'q!'` in the cases the terminal does _not_ respond and we need to wait for a timeout. Might still make sense for some sensible value of X.

> [@rmuir](https://github.com/rmuir) would you mind opening a new issue? The original issue here is nonsense.

Yes, I'll open a new issue for this.
opened https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32769

labels.description: issue has been tracked to a specific commit
labels.name: has:bisected

milestone.description: Low priority items. We plan to work on this but don't have a target date.
milestone.title: backlog

title: Garbage output in stderr after quitting nvim --clean, regressed since 0.9.5
